qas.question: At what wavelength does the human eye become significantly less sensitive to light?
What sort of light is generated by IR lasers?
Up to what wavelength does the human eye perceive IR LED sources as red?
Up to what wavelength does the human eye perceive certain intense lights as being dull red in color?
What objects are notably bright in near IR?

plausible_answers.text: at various values typically between 700 nm and 800 nm

qas.question: What is the defined boundary between visible and infrared light?
At what wavelength does the human eye perceive red light?
What light is generated by an IR-passing photographic filter?
What objects are hard to see if all visible light leaks are blocked?
What value measures wavelengths as long as 1050?

context: <b9_0>The onset of infrared<b9_0/> is defined (according to different standards) <b5_0>at various values typically between 700 nm and 800 nm<b5_0/>, but the boundary between visible and infrared light is not precisely defined. The human eye is markedly less sensitive to light above <a0_0><b6_0>700<b6_0/> nm<a0_0/> wavelength, so longer wavelengths make insignificant contributions to scenes illuminated by common light sources. However, particularly intense <a1_0>near-IR<a1_0/> light (e.g., from IR lasers, IR LED sources, or from bright daylight with the visible light removed by colored gels) can be detected up to approximately <a2_0>780 nm<a2_0/>, and will be perceived as red light. Sources providing wavelengths as long as <a3_0>1050 nm<a3_0/> can be seen as a dull red glow in intense sources, causing some difficulty in <b7_0>near-IR<b7_0/> illumination of scenes in the dark (usually this practical problem is solved by indirect illumination). <a4_0><b8_0>Leaves<b8_0/><a4_0/> are particularly bright in the near IR, and if all visible light leaks from around an IR-filter are blocked, and the eye is given a moment to adjust to the extremely dim image coming through a visually opaque IR-passing photographic filter, it is possible to see the Wood effect that consists of IR-glowing foliage.
